channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: How Russia Often Benefits When Julian Assange Reveals the West’s Secrets
item.media:description: Julian Assange looking out from the Ecuadorean Embassy in London in February. Having lived there for four years, he is increasingly isolated.
item.description: American officials say Mr. Assange and WikiLeaks probably have no direct ties to Russian intelligence services. But the agendas of WikiLeaks and the Kremlin have often dovetailed.
item.dc:creator: JO BECKER, STEVEN ERLANGER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: With Impeachment Over, Brazil’s Next Challenge Is Its Flailing Economy
item.description: The new president, Michel Temer, must navigate his own controversies and a quarrelsome Congress to lead Latin America’s largest nation out of a deepening fiscal crisis.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Dilma Rousseff Is Ousted as Brazil’s President in Impeachment Vote
item.description: The vote to convict Ms. Rousseff on charges of manipulating the federal budget was also a verdict on her leadership and Brazil’s eroding fortunes.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Mexicans Accuse President of ‘Historic Error’ in Welcoming Donald Trump
item.media:description: President Enrique Peña Nieto this month at the National Palace in Mexico City. He has been criticized for setting up a meeting with Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential nominee.
item.description: Many Mexican citizens are angry that President Enrique Peña Nieto would meet with Mr. Trump, let alone extend him an invitation.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED and ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Report Finds Ban Hasn’t Halted Use of Cluster Bombs in Syria or Yemen
item.media:description: Yemenis at a protest in January outside the United Nations offices in Sana, the capital, shouted anti-Saudi slogans and carried the remains of a cluster bomb believed to have been dropped in Saudi-led airstrikes.
item.description: Most of the world’s countries have signed a treaty banning the munitions, but not the United States and Russia, where many such bombs were made.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Spokesman’s Death Will Have Islamic State Turning to Its ‘Deep Bench’
item.media:description: Abu Muhammad al-Adnani, the Islamic State militant group’s spokesman, was reported killed in northern Syria by the group’s media.
item.media:credit: SITE Intel Group, via Associated Press
item.description: Though a lethal drone strike demonstrates progress against the militant group, ISIS has proved to be remarkably resilient and well prepared for the succession of key figures.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT, RUKMINI CALLIMACHI and ANNE BARNARD
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Rome Journal: With Mother Teresa Set to Be Canonized, Her Work Lives On in the Streets
item.media:description: Sisters of the Missionaries of Charity, the religious congregation founded by Mother Teresa in 1950, receiving communion during Mass at a motherhouse in Rome last week.
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.description: Her Missionaries of Charity religious congregation has continued to grow, serving the poor around the world, and just outside the seat of the Roman Catholic Church.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Islam Karimov, Uzbekistan’s President, Is Gravely Ill. No, Wait! He’s Fine.
item.media:description: Islam Karimov, left, the president of Uzbekistan, at a wreath-laying in Moscow in April.
item.description: The mystery surrounding the health of the Uzbek leader has historical roots in the old Soviet Union.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Myanmar Peace Talks Begin, High in Symbolism and in Skepticism
item.media:description: Attendees at the opening ceremony on Wednesday of a peace conference in Naypyidaw, Myanmar, included, from left, Senior General Min Aung Hlaing; Mahn Win Khaing Than, the speaker of the upper house of Parliament; Vice President Henry Van Thio; and Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the country’s leader.
item.description: The country’s leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, opened a conference intended to bring together hundreds of ethnic armed groups and end decades of conflict.
item.dc:creator: STÉPHANIE GIRY and WAI MOE

item.title: Shibar Journal: In Afghanistan’s Farm Belt, Women Lead Unions and Find New Status
item.media:description: Women who are part of a farmers union last month in the Shibar Valley in Bamian Province, Afghanistan.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: The farmers’ unions have helped ensure a more reliable and diverse food supply in an often famine-struck region, while also empowering its female leadership.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Human Bones Found Near Former Nazi Research Site in Berlin
item.description: Archaeologists in Berlin have unearthed a large number of human bones from a site close to where Nazi scientists carried out research on body parts of death camp victims sent to them by sadistic SS doctor Josef Mengele, officials said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of Turkish History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates back to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Violence After Gabon Elections Leaves One Dead
item.media:description: Police officers in Gabon on patrol near the National Assembly in Libreville, the capital, on Thursday.
item.description: Security forces in the West African nation clashed with opposition supporters after the declaration of a second term for President Ali Bongo Ondimba.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY and JAIME YAYA BARRY

item.title: Gabon’s President, Ali Bongo Ondimba, Is Re-Elected in Disputed Result
item.media:description: A supporter of the opposition leader Jean Ping lay wounded in Libreville on Wednesday during clashes with the riot police.
item.description: The Central African nation was bracing for violence after Mr. Bongo won an election that supporters of his opponent, Jean Ping, claimed was fraudulent.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: France’s Burkini Debate Reverberates Around the World
item.media:description: A woman in a burkini this month in Marseille, France.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: In other countries, the body-covering swimwear has been embraced as a symbol of modesty, liberation and even diversity.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: African Elephant Population Dropped 30 Percent in 7 Years
item.media:description: An African elephant at the Mpala Research Center and Wildlife Foundation in Kenya.
item.description: The decline is accelerating: Largely because of poaching, the African elephant population is dropping 8 percent a year.
item.dc:creator: NIRAJ CHOKSHI

item.title: A Summer Music School for Stars, Amateurs and Students
item.media:description: Violinists performing in front of the Great Hall at Dartington.
item.description: A mix of classical-music lovers gathered for concerts and classes at the Dartington International Summer School and Festival in Devon, England.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL WHITE
item.category: Dartington International Summer School and Festival

item.title: Fatal Beating of Polish Man Fuels Debate Over Xenophobia in Britain
item.media:description: A vigil for Arkadiusz Jozwik, who died from injuries sustained during an attack in Harlow, England.
item.media:credit: Chris Radburn/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: As the police investigate whether the killing of Arkadiusz Jozwik, 40, was motivated by hate, Poland’s ambassador expressed alarm.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Australian Writer Denounces Government’s Offshore Detention Policy
item.media:description: A protest in Sydney, Australia, last week over the country’s offshore detention policy for asylum seekers and refugees.
item.media:credit: Hugh Peterswald/Pacific Press/LightRocket, via Getty Images
item.description: Richard Flanagan described the suffering by refugees and asylum seekers held on the islands of Nauru and Manus as so extreme that it has been compared to torture.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Sinosphere: China’s ‘Core Socialist Values,’ the Song-and-Dance Version
item.description: In Hunan Province, the authorities have come up with 20 “square dance” routines to extol qualities like patriotism, dedication and equality.
item.dc:creator: KIKI ZHAO

item.title: Hong Kong Independence Movement Contests Beijing at the Polls
item.media:description: Sixtus Leung, known as Baggio, is running for Legislative Council as a member of the Youngspiration party. He is part of a new, youthful force in Hong Kong that is on the cusp of acquiring a measure of actual power.
item.media:credit: Billy H.C. Kwok for The New York Times
item.description: A new, youthful force, supporting some degree of greater self-determination for Hong Kong, may acquire a small measure of actual power in the election on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE and ALAN WONG

item.title: Bags of Cocaine Worth $56 Million Are Found at Coca-Cola Factory in France
item.media:description: Bottles of Coca-Cola on an assembly line at a factory near Paris.
item.description: The cocaine amounted to 370 kilograms and was stowed in a shipment of orange juice concentrate to the plant in the town of Signes.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER MELE

item.title: The Interpreter: All Impeachments Are Political. But Was Brazil’s Something More Sinister?
item.media:description: Senators celebrated Wednesday after voting to remove Dilma Rousseff as the president of Brazil.
item.description: Supporters of Dilma Rousseff say her opponents exploited the law to oust her as president. While there is some truth to that, Brazil’s political system itself may be to blame.
item.dc:creator: AMANDA TAUB
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Obama Heads to Asia Seeking Breakthrough on Trade and Climate Change
item.media:description: President Obama boarding Air Force One in Reno, Nev., on Wednesday, en route to Hawaii.
item.description: He is hoping to announce progress with China on the Paris climate accord and will state his case with other Asian countries on the Trans-Pacific Partnership.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: Donald Trump Gambles on Immigration but Sends Conflicting Signals
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump and President Enrique Peña Nieto held a joint press conference in Mexico City on Wednesday.
item.media:credit: Rodrigo Cruz for The New York Times
item.description: Mr. Trump’s dual speeches in Mexico City and Phoenix were so jarring that his true vision and intentions on immigration were hard to discern.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK HEALY

item.title: Study Finds Increase in Temporary Paralysis Accompanied Zika Outbreaks
item.media:description: Zulay Balza, right, recovering from Guillain-Barre syndrome in February at a hospital in Colombia. Ms. Balza did not show symptoms of the Zika virus; only one in five infected people do.
item.description: The analysis adds to substantial evidence that Zika infections — even asymptomatic ones — may bring on a paralysis called Guillain-Barré syndrome.
item.dc:creator: CATHERINE SAINT LOUIS

item.title: Mariano Rajoy Fails to Gain Backing for Spain’s New Government
item.media:description: Mariano Rajoy, Spain’s acting prime minister, attended a parliamentary debate in Madrid on Wednesday.
item.description: Lawmakers voted down the plan by Mr. Rajoy, the caretaker prime minister, raising the likelihood of a third national election.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Trying to Smoke Out the Players in the Hacking of the D.N.C.
item.media:description: President Obama and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia during a meeting at the United Nations last year.
item.description: A tangle of questions about what might connect Guccifer, the Russians, WikiLeaks and the Democratic National Committee.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Justin Trudeau Is on the Cover of a Marvel Comic Book. He Is Now a King Among Memes.
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada on the cover of Marvel’s “Civil War II: Choosing Sides No. 5.”
item.description: The Canadian prime minister is on a variant cover available in shops and is an integral part of the story. His father was featured in a Marvel comic in 1979.
item.dc:creator: KAREN WORKMAN

item.title: Court Throws Out $655.5 Million Terrorism Verdict Against Palestinian Groups
item.description: A three-judge panel in New York reversed a ruling that had held the Palestinian Authority and the Palestine Liberation Organization liable for supporting attacks in Israel that killed Americans.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: World’s Oldest Fossils Found in Greenland
item.media:description: Stromatolites from the Isua area of Greenland may be the oldest fossil evidence of life on Earth.
item.description: The find, thought to be layers of sediment packed together by microbial communities living in shallow water, could alter our understanding of how life evolved.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS WADE

item.title: Russia Claims Credit for Killing Senior ISIS Leader in Syria
item.media:description: An image of Abu Muhammad al-Adnani posted online Wednesday by supporters of the Islamic State.
item.description: The Pentagon quickly dismissed the claim, a challenge to an American report that one of its drone strikes had killed Abu Muhammad al-Adnani in Syria.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Suspicions Confirmed: Couple Faked Photographs in Everest Climb
item.media:description: Trekkers near the Mount Everest base camp in Nepal in February.
item.description: They claimed they were the first Indian couple to ascend the world’s highest peak, but their “proof” consisted of clumsy forgeries, as many climbers had said.
item.dc:creator: KAI SCHULTZ and NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Highlights of Donald Trump’s Immigration Speech and Mexico Trip
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump at his campaign event in Phoenix on Wednesday.
item.media:credit: Travis Dove for The New York Times
item.description: In Mexico, Mr. Trump said he focused on the two nations’ shared economic and security interests, and discussed his plan to build a border wall. In Arizona, what he said was startlingly different.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL BARBARO, ALEX BURNS, MAGGIE HABERMAN and KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Chinese School With Mass Illness Is Deemed Safe, but Many Doubt Findings
item.media:description: The campus of the Changzhou Foreign Languages School in Jiangsu Province, China, in April, after state TV reported nearly 500 illnesses there.
item.description: The city of Changzhou says tests have cleared the school that became a focus of national outrage when nearly 500 students got sick. But questions persist.
item.dc:creator: KIKI ZHAO

item.title: 2 Months After ‘Brexit’ Vote, Britain’s Push to Leave E.U. Is a Muddle
item.description: Between turf wars and competing interests, the government is having trouble devising a coherent plan for ending four decades of integration with Europe.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Yesterday, Outraged by Apple’s Tax Dodge. Today, by Its Tax Bill.
item.media:description: Employees standing in front of a screen displaying iPhones during a preview event in July at the new Apple Store in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The European Union told Ireland on Tuesday that it must collect $14.5 billion in back taxes from Apple.
item.description: Lawmakers have criticized companies that avoid taxes by moving overseas. But they’re rallying to Apple’s defense after an E.U. demand for $14.5 billion in back taxes.
item.dc:creator: ALAN RAPPEPORT

item.title: Canada to Join China-Led Bank, Signaling Readiness to Bolster Ties
item.media:description: Justin Trudeau, left, the prime minister of Canada, and Li Keqiang, the premier of China, during a ceremony in Beijing on Wednesday.
item.description: The membership would provide a lift for the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, which is widely seen as a counterweight to the World Bank.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Obama Begins His Final Asia Trip as President
item.media:description: President Obama leaving Walter Reed National Military Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., on Friday.
item.description: He will visit China, Laos and Midway Atoll, where he will announce an expansion of a marine preserve and speak about the perils of climate change.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: Marc Riboud, Photojournalist Who Found Grace in the Turbulent, Dies at 93
item.media:description: Marc Riboud worked on the front lines of world events, but he also loved taking photographs of anonymous citizens.
item.description: A protégé of Henri Cartier-Bresson, Mr. Riboud routinely traveled to restive places throughout Asia and Africa in the 1950s and ’60s as part of his decades-long career.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD B. WOODWARD

item.title: Scheduled Flights to Cuba From U.S. Begin Again, Now With Jet Engines
item.description: The last time that an airline in the United States had a regularly scheduled flight to the island, the passengers flew on a propeller plane.
item.dc:creator: FRANCES ROBLES

item.title: North Korea Has Executed a Deputy Premier, Seoul Reports
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, in a picture issued by his government’s Korean Central News Agency.
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, has executed the deputy premier for education, Kim Yong-jin, and purged two other senior officials, South Korea said.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: What in the World: How Some Chinese Men Meet Summer’s Swelter: With Midriff Bare and Bulging
item.media:description: A man near Beijing’s Forbidden City this month rolled up his shirt, a way to keep cool known as the Beijing bikini.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: Nothing defines China’s hottest days more than the Beijing Bikini: grown men, without a hint of shame, rolling up shirts to expose often generous bellies.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: What in the World: Never the Noodles Shall Meet: A Chinese Treaty Is Tested
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin; photo by DoctorPic/Shutterstock
item.description: Halal food is big business in China. But to the Hui, a Muslim ethnic minority, a social pact may come before profit in the placement of halal noodle shops.
item.dc:creator: EMILY FENG

item.title: Editorial: Gridlock in Spain
item.description: A coalition with hostile factions hardly promises effective governance, but a messy government is better than none at all.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Why Is Turkey Accusing Me of Plotting a Coup?
item.description: Turkish anti-Americanism is out of control. President Obama must try to put a stop to it before it’s too late.
item.dc:creator: HENRI J. BARKEY
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Editorial: Donald Trump’s Deportation Nation
item.description: A trip to Mexico and a speech in Phoenix don’t add substance to Donald Trump’s bluster about thwarting evil foreigners.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Readers React: Seeing Orange: What Caught Commenters’ Eyes About a Small Syrian Boy in a Big Chair
item.media:description: Omran Daqneesh, 5, was rescued after an airstrike in the Syrian city of Aleppo.
item.description: Our Photo Editors’ Notebook on what made the image of Omran Daqneesh stand out inspired many readers to share their thoughts.
item.dc:creator: INSIDER STAFF
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Notebook: How Many Guns Did the U.S. Lose Track of in Iraq and Afghanistan? Hundreds of Thousands.
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers after receiving new rifles from U.S. forces in Baghdad in May 2007.
item.description: A new study shows how the American military failed at the soldier’s most basic responsibility: keeping track of firearms.
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Talking to Terrorists
item.media:description: Harry Sarfo, a former Islamic State fighter from Germany, inside the maximum-security prison in Bremen where he is serving a three-year sentence on terrorism charges.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: For once, the conversation wasn’t via social media, and the name the Islamic State defector used was the one on his birth certificate.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
